Award.AwardTitle: EARS: Title: Energy-Efficient Millimeter-wave Communication via Adaptation and Reconfiguration

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Energy-Efficient mm-wave Communication via Adaptation and Reconfiguration
Jeyanandh Paramesh and Pulkit Grover, CMU

Intellectual Merit: In 2013, the number of interconnected devices exceeded the number of human beings on the planet, and the number continues to grow at a rapid pace. Applications running on these devices demand ever increasing data rates, the devices are increasingly wireless, and operate in dynamic, short-distance environments. To enable fast, reliable, and consistent access to radio spectrum, two approaches are being pursued: spectrum-sharing /cognitive radio and networks augmented with short-range millimeter-wave links. The energy consumption of mobile devices has become a bottleneck, and the energy overhead of new spectrum access approaches remains unclear. Today's systems are designed with fixed parameters that enable them to work in worst-case environments. With energy-minimization as our goal, we propose to design, analyze, and prototype system components that are able to respond and adapt dynamically to the environment in order to operate at minimal system-level energy in changing environments. These designs rely on hardware (e.g RF/mixed-signal circuits and sub-systems such as beamformers,), algorithms (e.g. equalization, decoding), and communication strategy (e.g. the error-correcting code) that are adaptable and reconfigurable in compatible ways so that they minimize system-level energy. Rigorous modeling, testing, and implementation as well as strategy design and comparison with fundamental limits on system-level power consumption will be performed.
We will take a cross-disciplinary approach to investigate system-level energy minimization of mmW communication systems. To adapt to variability in the communication environment, we will design and implement adaptive and reconfigurable systems. By using fundamental limits on system performance, we will develop insights and algorithms that approach these limits. The designed systems will be used to obtain models and parameters for system-level energy-minimization which will in turn will help understand the benefits of adaptation and reconfigurability. The research outcomes will impact: second generation mmW networks in the 60 GHz band, future mmW cellular systems, data-intensive cyber-physical systems, wireless BigData processing systems etc.
The Broader Impacts include: (i) training of new scientists with expertise in cross-disciplinary research; (ii) development of new courses "Advanced Communication ICs" and "The Science of Information" by synthesis of concepts in coding theory and circuits; (iii) development of course projects for undergraduate circuits classes based on implementation of error-correcting codes and equalizers; (iii) development of theoretical tools for system design and analysis that go beyond our exemplar applications, such as wired Ethernet communication; (iv) training undergraduate students in practical, theoretical, and cross-disciplinary research through internships; and (iv) focus on inclusion of under-represented minorities and women in this research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wireless communication has had an immeasurable economic, societal and scientific impact worldwide. However, with the continuing explosion of smartphones, tablets, sensor swarms, the internet of things etc., worldwide mobile data traffic is expected to exceed 66,000 PB/month (petabytes) in 2022, up from 94 PB/month in 2010.  While almost all commercial wireless communication currently occupies frequency bands below 6 GHz, it is now widely accepted that the exploitation of new spectrum in the 20-100 GHz range (roughly called millimeter-wave) is the only viable approach that can meet this projected demand. However, compared to sub-6 GHz communication, significantly new hardware technology is required at mm-wave. Accordingly, the research outcomes of this project titled "Energy-Efficient Millimeter-wave Communication via Adaptation and Reconfiguration" span technological and theoretical foundations.

 Technological Foundations: We have developed several advanced transceivers for millimeter-wave beamforming and MIMO, along with underlying circuit innovation to enable high energy-efficiency and compact footprint. These include (a) a phased-array receiver in 45 nm CMOS with the widest reported bandwidth (45-66 GHz) to date, (b) the first millimeter-wave MIMO receiver in the literature and (3) a reconfigurable 28/37 GHz adaptive beamformer supporting "carrier aggregation" and/or multi-Standard MIMO communication. Additionally, we have conducted exploratory studies towards digital mm-wave beamforming transceivers.

 Theoretical Foundations: A new model for abstracting energy consumed in VLSI circuits, called the "Information Friction Model" has been developed. [Grover, IEEE Trans. Information Theory, 2015]. The team used this model to derive novel fundamental limits including circuit energy, especially in encoding and decoding circuitry. These results demonstrate that Shannon-theoretic understanding, which ignores encoding/decoding energy, is optimistic and can provide misleading techniques for system-level optimization. This work has been published in several inter-disciplinary publications spanning circuits and information theory, culminating in [Ganesan, Goldsmith, Rabaey, Grover, IEEE JSAC'16] which demonstrated that the fundamental limits abstract the most relevant terms, namely, energy consumed in wires, for decoding circuits for modern codes.

 Technology Transfer: Technologies developed in this project have been disseminated through academic publications, invention disclosures, patent filings and seminars in industry and academia. Over ten publications on technological foundations have resulted at top venues including the International Solid-State Circuits Conference, the IEEE Radio-Frequency Integrated Circuits Symposium, GLOBECOM, IEEE Journal of Solid-State Circuits, IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems and the IEEE Transactions of Microwave Theory and Techniques. Work on theoretical foundations has been published in several publications in top conferences such as IEEE ISIT, NIPS, etc. and in top journals such as IEEE Trans. Info Theory and IEEE Journal for Selected Areas in Communications.

 Four invention disclosures have been filed, leading to one patent application filing and two provisional patents (with efforts underway to file utility patents).  Furthermore, the physical technologies developed in this project will be used as the basis for a first-of-its-kind mmWave multiple-input-multiple-output (MIMO) capable network testbed comprising base stations and mobile user modules spanning indoor and outdoor spaces. [Ref: NSF Award #1823235  CRI: II-New: Mobile Millimeter-Wave MIMO Network Based on CMU Chipscale Beamformers]

 Regular interactions with industry have enabled technology transfer.  PI Paramesh gave regular talks to companies with ongoing efforts in the 5G space, and to the wide technical community in his capacity as Distinguished Lecturer for the IEEE Solid-State Circuits Society. PI Grover gave regular talks to the industry through a platform provided by Semiconductor Research Corporation's SONIC Research Center. He and his students also met industry researchers on a roughly bimonthly basis, informing them about research advances in the EARS award.

 Training and Professional Development: This project has partially or fully supported  6 PhD students (3 graduated). Rahul Singh, Mazen Soliman, Ahmed Hussein and Susnata Mondal have focused on technological foundations while  female PhD students Haewon Jeong and Sanghamitra Dutta have made fundamental contributions to communication and computing under energy constraints. Funds were also used to support several undergraduate students including minority undergraduate female students Jecolia Longtchi, Rahshel Brown and Arnelle Etienne, who are planning to pursue higher education.
